Award.AwardTitle: Neutrino Astrophysics at the University of Maryland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Embedded deep in the ice cap at the South Pole, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory (ICNO) is the world's largest and most sensitive high energy neutrino telescope. It is a 1 billion-ton detector using the Antarctic ice as a detection medium for high energy atmospheric and astrophysical neutrinos. Most of the neutrinos observed by IceCube exhibit energies in the range expected for atmospheric neutrinos originating from decays of particles produced in extensive air showers by cosmic rays coming from nearby sectors of the Milky Way Galaxy. These may be used to measure the fundamental properties of neutrinos. At higher energies, astrophysical neutrinos are key probes of the high-energy universe. Because of their unique properties, neutrinos escape even dense regions, are not deflected by galactic or extra-galactic magnetic fields and traverse the photon-filled universe unhindered. Thus, neutrinos provide direct information about the dynamics and interiors of the powerful cosmic objects that may be the origins of high energy cosmic rays: supernovae, black holes, pulsars, active galactic nuclei and other extreme extragalactic phenomena.

This particle astrophysics group has a record of providing research and educational opportunities for students and early career scientists, as well as engaging the public and K-12 students to share the wonder of science. The impact of this work spans significantly beyond the field of neutrino astrophysics to the broader scientific category of multi-messenger and multi-wavelength astrophysics. A key element of this broader impact is the ongoing effort to develop a robust real-time neutrino alert and response system for the broader community.

The group plays an important role in the operation of the detector and management of the IceCube and Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) collaborations. This award will support continued analysis of IceCube data focusing on searches for neutrino emission from GRBs, real-time neutrino searches with increased alerts to the astronomical community, and searches for extremely high energy cosmogenic neutrinos. The search for cosmogenic neutrino signals in IceCube remains a critical area of scientific importance, where additional work is required to disentangle the observed astrophysical neutrino flux from potential cosmogenic signals. Research efforts here overlap with their work on the ARA radio detector and its mission to detect and measure cosmogenic neutrinos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to broaden our basic knowledge of the physical universe through the use and measurement of high-energy elementary particles called neutrinos. The neutrinos are used as astrophysical messenger particles, much like photon particles of light, by detecting them in the South Pole IceCube neutrino detector, which measures their energy, direction and lepton flavor in order to 1) elucidate the origin of high energy cosmic rays and determine the astrophysical mechanisms at work in the highest energy objects in the universe; and 2) use the neutrinos detected in the IceCube instrument to determine fundamental properties of the neutrinos themselves, which are one of the elementary building blocks of matter and could provide a unique way to study the landscape of Grand Unified Theories and the nature of CP violation. These are fundamental to understanding the origin of the dominance of ordinary matter over antimatter in our universe. 

Research from prior funding of this work resulted in a landmark discovery ushering in the new era of multi-messenger astrophysics. The result was the world?s first compelling evidence of an astrophysical source of both high-energy astrophysical neutrinos and photons from a distant active galaxy type called a blazar. The result was published as the  cover story in the Journal science in July of 2018. The simultaneous observation of high-energy neutrinos in coincidence with radio, optical, x-ray and gamma-ray observations of a flaring blazar are a quantum step forward in the field of multi-messenger astrophysics. In the decade to come, we hope to use this new multi-messenger astrophysics to improve our understanding of the extreme environments at work in the highest energy objects and processes at work in our universe and will hopefully solve the 100-year-old mystery of what is the source of the highest energy cosmic rays. 

This award funding has enabled our work building on the previous success of IceCube multi-messenger science. We have improved and updated the online real-time alert system used by IceCube that originally enabled the landmark discovery mentioned above with an improved version with a designated sample of higher signal purity and improved accuracy. We also worked on extending this system to produce rapid results on neutrino emission in response to gamma-ray burst alerts from the many photon detectors in the world?s astrophysical and astronomy communities. Gamma-ray bursts are brief, seconds to minutes duration, flaring events of high energy photons called gamma-rays that emit extreme amounts of energy in a short time, and whose detailed mechanisms for producing this emission are still not understood. Techniques were also developed to extend the neutrinos IceCube uses for astrophysical studies to lower energies then available previously. This should bring improved sensitivity to certain astrophysical models and objects for studying multi-messenger neutrino emission in the high-energy universe. During this award period we also produced a new result on the nature of neutrino flavor oscillations and tau neutrino appearance using the IceCube detector, published 2019 in the peer-reviewed scientific journal Physical Review D.
